articles.headline: Weak Links in China’s Food Chain
articles.snippet: The OSI Group, one of the top meat producers in the United States with more than $6 billion in sales and about 20,000 employees in 17 countries, is enveloped in a food safety scandal in China.
articles.abstract: The OSI Group, one of the top meat producers in the United States with more than $6 billion in sales and about 20,000 employees in 17 countries, is enveloped in a food safety scandal in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: When McDonald’s opened its first restaurant in China in the early 1990s, it did not turn to local suppliers for meat, which most likely would have been cheaper. Instead, it relied on its longtime partner the OSI Group, which had been linked to the fast-food titan ever since Ray Kroc, the McDonald’s founder, in the 1950s tapped the Chicago butcher Otto & Sons to provide consistent, reliable meats to his expanding empire.

articles.headline: To Lift Sales, G.M. Turns to Discounts
articles.snippet: The automaker has piled on cash incentives and cheap lease deals to invigorate sales of its passenger cars, particularly the smaller models.
articles.abstract: The automaker has piled on cash incentives and cheap lease deals to invigorate sales of its passenger cars, particularly the smaller models.
articles.lead_paragraph: In February, General Motors hit a milestone of sorts when its sales incentives, as tracked by the research firm Edmunds.com, dropped below those of its domestic rivals, Ford and Chrysler.
articles.byline: By Aaron M. Kessler and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: MoneyPak, a Popular Prepaid Money Card, Opens Path to Fraud Schemes
articles.snippet: The MoneyPak card, used to transfer cash by those without access to conventional bank accounts, has also caught the eye of criminals, from a Maryland jail gang to an online prostitution ring in North Carolina.
articles.abstract: The MoneyPak card, used to transfer cash by those without access to conventional bank accounts, has also caught the eye of criminals, from a Maryland jail gang to an online prostitution ring in North Carolina.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal authorities are sounding alarms about a wide range of fraudulent schemes involving a popular prepaid money card product.

articles.headline: Alibaba Is Investing Huge Sums in an Array of U.S. Tech Companies
articles.snippet: The Chinese retail giant has made a half-dozen major investments in American start-ups over the last year, focusing on mobile and e-commerce.
articles.abstract: The Chinese retail giant has made a half-dozen major investments in American start-ups over the last year, focusing on mobile and e-commerce.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet retailer, is coming to America with its checkbook wide open.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Gaza Fighting Intensifies as Cease-Fire Falls Apart
articles.snippet: A cease-fire in Gaza collapsed on Friday as the Israeli military said that two soldiers had been killed and a third apparently captured. Gaza health officials said at least 70 Palestinians had been killed by Israeli airstrikes.
articles.abstract: A cease-fire in Gaza collapsed on Friday as the Israeli military said that two soldiers had been killed and a third apparently captured. Gaza health officials said at least 70 Palestinians had been killed by Israeli airstrikes.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Palestinian militants sprang from the ground and confronted Israeli soldiers Friday morning, as they have repeatedly in recent days. This time, Israeli officials said, one exploded a suicide belt while another unleashed machine-gun fire. This time, two Israeli soldiers were killed and the militants apparently escaped with a third.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: More Rejoin Labor Force; Jobless Rate Up to 6.2%
articles.snippet: The government said 209,000 jobs were created in July, while economists had expected about 230,000. The unemployment rate inched up to 6.2 percent.
articles.abstract: The government said 209,000 jobs were created in July, while economists had expected about 230,000. The unemployment rate inched up to 6.2 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Little to rave or rant about.

articles.headline: Summer Job? Time to Start a Roth I.R.A.
articles.snippet: Opening a retirement savings account as a teenager instead of a few years after college can lead to hundreds of thousands of extra dollars after a half-century of growth.
articles.abstract: Opening a retirement savings account as a teenager instead of a few years after college can lead to hundreds of thousands of extra dollars after a half-century of growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: When teenagers earn money for the first time, there are so many things they can do with it.
